title: Rotational equilibrium compare alpha perp rods

content.question: A pair of identical rods, each of length <math alttext="L sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, are rigidly attached at a right angle, as shown in the figure. The rods pivot around an axis perpendicular to the plane of the figure and located where the rods are joined. In each of two experimental trials, two forces of the same magnitude <math alttext="F sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> are exerted on the two-rod system as shown. Which of the following correctly compares the magnitudes <math alttext="alpha sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="alpha sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> of the angular acceleration of the systems in trials <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, respectively?

choices.label: <math alttext="alpha sub 1 is greater than alpha sub 2, which equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>

<math alttext="alpha sub 1 is greater than alpha sub 2, which does not equal 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></math>

<math alttext="alpha sub 2 is greater than alpha sub 1, which equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>

<math alttext="alpha sub 2 is greater than alpha sub 1, which does not equal 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="alpha sub 1 is greater than alpha sub 2, which equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>

topic.text: 5.5: Rotational Equilibrium and Newton's First Law in Rotational Form

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
